elements.content: A fluorous metal−organic framework, FMOF-1, is obtained by reaction of Ag(I) with 3,5-bis(trifluoromethyl)-1,2,4-triazolate, giving rise to a neutral, hydrogen-free, extended 3D nanotubular porous framework consisting of tetranuclear clusters [Ag4Tz6] connected by three-coordinate Ag(I) centers. The fluoro-lined channels and cavities of the framework show hysteretic adsorption of H2 with a volumetric capacity of 41 kg/m3 at 77 K and 64 bar. The framework also exhibits very high adsorptions for O2 and N2 with volumetric uptake of ∼550 and 400 kg/m3 at 77 K even at very low pressures (<10-2 bar).
elements.clean_text: A fluorous metal-organic framework, FMOF-1, is obtained by reaction of Ag(I) with 3,5-bis(trifluoromethyl)-1,2,4-triazolate, giving rise to a neutral, hydrogen-free, extended 3D nanotubular porous framework consisting of tetranuclear clusters [Ag4Tz6] connected by three-coordinate Ag(I) centers. The fluoro-lined channels and cavities of the framework show hysteretic adsorption of H2 with a volumetric capacity of 41 kg/m3 at 77 K and 64 bar. The framework also exhibits very high adsorptions for O2 and N2 with volumetric uptake of ~550 and 400 kg/m3 at 77 K even at very low pressures (<10-2 bar).

elements.content: The search for new crystalline porous materials, either with an inorganic or a metal−organic framework (MOF), is very topical as fueled by the use of such materials in a range of applications. These include catalysis, separations, gas storage, ion-exchange, sensors, and optoelectronics. In particular, stable MOFs with permanent channels or cavities may become effective, convenient, safe, and cost-effective gas-storage materials for fuel-cell-driven automobiles in the near future. Extensive efforts have been devoted to the rational design and construction of new MOFs with zeolite-like, well-defined, stable micro- or mesopore-size channels exhibiting higher, more reversible, or more selective gas affinity. Pioneered by Yaghi et al., a vast number of organic ligands with a variety of donor groups and over 40 metal cations have been explored in MOF construction.
elements.clean_text: The search for new crystalline porous materials, either with an inorganic or a metal-organic framework (MOF), is very topical as fueled by the use of such materials in a range of applications. These include catalysis, separations, gas storage, ion-exchange, sensors, and optoelectronics. In particular, stable MOFs with permanent channels or cavities may become effective, convenient, safe, and cost-effective gas-storage materials for fuel-cell-driven automobiles in the near future. Extensive efforts have been devoted to the rational design and construction of new MOFs with zeolite-like, well-defined, stable micro- or mesopore-size channels exhibiting higher, more reversible, or more selective gas affinity. Pioneered by Yaghi et al., a vast number of organic ligands with a variety of donor groups and over 40 metal cations have been explored in MOF construction.

elements.content: Inspired by the unusual stability, extraordinary functional properties, and numerous applications of fluorous molecules, we have ignited an effort to explore the synthesis and functional properties of fluorous metal−organic frameworks (FMOFs), wherein hydrogen atoms are substituted by fluorine atoms in all ligands. Compared to their non-fluorous counterparts, FMOFs with fluoro-lined or fluoro-coated channels or cavities are expected to possess enhanced thermal stability and catalytic activity, higher gas affinity and selectivity, and higher stability to oxidation and light. In addition, fluorination may impart a variety of new functional properties to FMOFs, such as superacidity, enhanced hydrophobicity, low surface energy and surface tension, low refractive index, exceptional chemical and biological inertness, and excellent optical and electrical properties. Many nanoscale fluorous environments have been created mainly via self-assembly processes, including nanoballs, channels, micelles, vesicles, microbubbles, tubules, and hollow fibers. However, porous FMOFs providing a perfluorinated pore surface are yet unknown among reported MOFs.
elements.clean_text: Inspired by the unusual stability, extraordinary functional properties, and numerous applications of fluorous molecules, we have ignited an effort to explore the synthesis and functional properties of fluorous metal-organic frameworks (FMOFs), wherein hydrogen atoms are substituted by fluorine atoms in all ligands. Compared to their non-fluorous counterparts, FMOFs with fluoro-lined or fluoro-coated channels or cavities are expected to possess enhanced thermal stability and catalytic activity, higher gas affinity and selectivity, and higher stability to oxidation and light. In addition, fluorination may impart a variety of new functional properties to FMOFs, such as superacidity, enhanced hydrophobicity, low surface energy and surface tension, low refractive index, exceptional chemical and biological inertness, and excellent optical and electrical properties. Many nanoscale fluorous environments have been created mainly via self-assembly processes, including nanoballs, channels, micelles, vesicles, microbubbles, tubules, and hollow fibers. However, porous FMOFs providing a perfluorinated pore surface are yet unknown among reported MOFs.

elements.content: This work is in the context of ongoing efforts that we have recently launched to study the structure, optoelectronic properties and acid−base chemistry of coinage-metal triazolates. The work herein demonstrates an expansion of the potential of such materials to include FMOFs. A few reports on MOFs utilizing non-fluorinated metal triazolates have recently appeared. One of our strategies to obtain porous FMOFs with fluoro-lined channels exploits robust, perfluorinated metal−triazolate clusters as building blocks, which bear unsaturated metal sites and exo-N donor atoms. Such building blocks, therefore, can readily assemble into coordination polymers with 1-, 2-, or 3D framework structures.
elements.clean_text: This work is in the context of ongoing efforts that we have recently launched to study the structure, optoelectronic properties and acid-base chemistry of coinage-metal triazolates. The work herein demonstrates an expansion of the potential of such materials to include FMOFs. A few reports on MOFs utilizing non-fluorinated metal triazolates have recently appeared. One of our strategies to obtain porous FMOFs with fluoro-lined channels exploits robust, perfluorinated metal-triazolate clusters as building blocks, which bear unsaturated metal sites and exo-N donor atoms. Such building blocks, therefore, can readily assemble into coordination polymers with 1-, 2-, or 3D framework structures.

elements.content: The sodium salt of the perfluorinated ligand 3,5-bis(trifluoromethyl)-1,2,4-triazolate (NaTz), reacts with silver nitrate in methanol to afford colorless crystals upon evaporation and recrystallization from acetonitrile/toluene. The crystallinity remains intact after evacuating the crystals by heating at 100 °C under vacuum overnight. Analysis of the evacuated crystals by single-crystal X-ray diffraction reveals a neutral FMOF with the formula {Ag2[Ag4Tz6]} n , FMOF-1. The crystal structure of FMOF-1 shows extended 3D nanotubular open frameworks consisting of six-connected tetranuclear [Ag4Tz6] clusters linked by three-coordinate Ag(I) centers (Figure ). The six triazolate ligands utilize their 1- and 2-positioned N-atoms to link four four-coordinate Ag(2) atoms into tetranuclear [Ag4Tz6] clusters with adjacent Ag(2)−Ag(2) distance of 3.469(1) Å. The equatorial Ag(2)−N(4) and Ag(2)−N(5) distances are 2.18(1) and 2.18(1) Å, respectively, and the axial Ag(2)−N(2) distance is 2.62(1) Å. The [Ag4Tz6] clusters are interconnected via three-coordinate Ag(1) atoms through the 4-positioned N atoms of the triazolate ligands, with Ag(1)−N(1) = 2.21(1), Ag(1)−N(3) = 2.272(9) Å, and N(1)−Ag(1)−N(3) = 128.1(2)°, generating a 3D framework of (42·6)(44·62·88·10) topology (see Figure S1 in the Supporting Information). The framework consists of interconnected large open-ended, hollow tubes extending along both the a- and b-axes, and the hollow tubes intersect at crystallographically imposed special positions with an S 4 point-group symmetry. The cylindrical channels of the tubular framework possess hydrophobic internal cavities, as the CF3 groups of the perfluorinated ligands point into the channels. A cross section of each fluoro-lined channel in the space-filling representation entails a semirectangular shape with ∼12.2 Å × 7.3 Å dimensions. The walls of the channels consist of diamond-shaped small cavities with ∼6.6 Å × 4.9 Å dimensions (Figure d). Each cavity is formed by two adjacent [Ag4Tz6] clusters interconnected by two Ag(I) atoms. Two pairs of channel-surface CF3 groups located on top of the cavity function as a gate for the small cavity to communicate with the large channel. The fluoro-lined channels account for 40.8% of the unit cell volume as calculated by PLATON, which is the highest in metal−triazolate frameworks16 and comparable to the best high-porosity MOFs.
elements.clean_text: The sodium salt of the perfluorinated ligand 3,5-bis(trifluoromethyl)-1,2,4-triazolate (NaTz), reacts with silver nitrate in methanol to afford colorless crystals upon evaporation and recrystallization from acetonitrile/toluene. The crystallinity remains intact after evacuating the crystals by heating at 100 °C under vacuum overnight. Analysis of the evacuated crystals by single-crystal X-ray diffraction reveals a neutral FMOF with the formula {Ag2[Ag4Tz6]} n , FMOF-1. The crystal structure of FMOF-1 shows extended 3D nanotubular open frameworks consisting of six-connected tetranuclear [Ag4Tz6] clusters linked by three-coordinate Ag(I) centers (Figure ). The six triazolate ligands utilize their 1- and 2-positioned N-atoms to link four four-coordinate Ag(2) atoms into tetranuclear [Ag4Tz6] clusters with adjacent Ag(2)-Ag(2) distance of 3.469(1) Å. The equatorial Ag(2)-N(4) and Ag(2)-N(5) distances are 2.18(1) and 2.18(1) Å, respectively, and the axial Ag(2)-N(2) distance is 2.62(1) Å. The [Ag4Tz6] clusters are interconnected via three-coordinate Ag(1) atoms through the 4-positioned N atoms of the triazolate ligands, with Ag(1)-N(1) = 2.21(1), Ag(1)-N(3) = 2.272(9) Å, and N(1)-Ag(1)-N(3) = 128.1(2)°, generating a 3D framework of (42⋅6)(44⋅62⋅88⋅10) topology (see Figure S1 in the Supporting Information). The framework consists of interconnected large open-ended, hollow tubes extending along both the a- and b-axes, and the hollow tubes intersect at crystallographically imposed special positions with an S 4 point-group symmetry. The cylindrical channels of the tubular framework possess hydrophobic internal cavities, as the CF3 groups of the perfluorinated ligands point into the channels. A cross section of each fluoro-lined channel in the space-filling representation entails a semirectangular shape with ~12.2 Å × 7.3 Å dimensions. The walls of the channels consist of diamond-shaped small cavities with ~6.6 Å × 4.9 Å dimensions (Figure d). Each cavity is formed by two adjacent [Ag4Tz6] clusters interconnected by two Ag(I) atoms. Two pairs of channel-surface CF3 groups located on top of the cavity function as a gate for the small cavity to communicate with the large channel. The fluoro-lined channels account for 40.8% of the unit cell volume as calculated by PLATON, which is the  highest in metal-triazolate frameworks16 and comparable to the best high-porosity MOFs.

elements.content: Structure ofFMOF-1 showing 50% thermal ellipsoidal plots of the building blocks consisting of a tetranuclear [Ag4Tz6] cluster (a) and three-coordinate Ag(I) centers (b), a space-filling representation of the large fluoro-lined channels (c), and a perspective view of the small cavities, denoted by black spheres, surrounding the large channels (d).
elements.clean_text: 1  Structure ofFMOF-1 showing 50% thermal ellipsoidal plots of the building blocks consisting of a tetranuclear [Ag4Tz6] cluster (a) and three-coordinate Ag(I) centers (b), a space-filling representation of the large fluoro-lined channels (c), and a perspective view of the small cavities, denoted by black spheres, surrounding the large channels (d).

elements.content: The architectural stability and porosity of FMOF-1 is confirmed by the gas adsorption results at 77 K (Figure ). The adsorption isotherms of O2 and N2 within FMOF-1 at low pressure show two pore-filling steps at log(P/P 0) of −4.0 and −3.2 for O2 and −4.0 and −2.7 for N2. It is reasonable to assign the first uptake to micropore filling of gas molecules into the large channels, whereas the second steep uptake is assigned to the small pores since the size of the latter (vide supra) can accommodate the dynamic size of the gas molecules studied herein (largest is N2, 4.1 Å × 3.0 Å). Fitting the BET equation to the N2 isotherm gives an apparent surface area of 810.5 m2/g and a pore volume of 0.324 cm3/g at P/P 0 = 0.978. These values surpass those of the most porous zeolites and are similar to those of the best-performing activated carbons and MOFs.
elements.clean_text: The architectural stability and porosity of FMOF-1 is confirmed by the gas adsorption results at 77 K (Figure ). The adsorption isotherms of O2 and N2 within FMOF-1 at low pressure show two pore-filling steps at log(P/P 0) of -4.0 and -3.2 for O2 and -4.0 and -2.7 for N2. It is reasonable to assign the first uptake to micropore filling of gas molecules into the large channels, whereas the second steep uptake is assigned to the small pores since the size of the latter (vide supra) can accommodate the dynamic size of the gas molecules studied herein (largest is N2, 4.1 Å × 3.0 Å). Fitting the BET equation to the N2 isotherm gives an apparent surface area of 810.5 m2/g and a pore volume of 0.324 cm3/g at P/P 0 = 0.978. These values surpass those of the most porous zeolites and are similar to those of the best-performing activated carbons and MOFs.

elements.content: Volumetric uptake of N2 and O2 gases (top), and H2 gas (bottom) within FMOF-1 at 77 K. (Inset) Isotherms of a low-pressure run of H2 adsorption/desorption cycle.
elements.clean_text: 2  Volumetric uptake of N2 and O2 gases (top), and H2 gas (bottom) within FMOF-1 at 77 K. (Inset) Isotherms of a low-pressure run of H2 adsorption/desorption cycle.

elements.content: The hydrogen-adsorption isotherm also shows a two-step filling profile similar to that of O2 and N2 at low pressure. Interestingly, the desorption isotherm does not retrace the adsorption isotherm and shows an abrupt drop at ∼14 bar. This remarkable hysteretic adsorption/desorption of H2 within FMOF-1, which has been reproduced three times, would allow H2 to be adsorbed at high pressures but stored at lower pressures. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first example of a hysteretic sorption behavior of supercritical H2 at a high-pressure range. The volumetric capacity of hydrogen within FMOF-1 at 77 K and 64 bar is 41 kg/m3, which is close to the DOE 2010 target of 45 kg/m3. Similar capacities have recently been reported at 77 K for Mn(II)−tetrazolate (43 kg/m3 at 90 bar) and Cu(II)−terphenyl-tetracarboxylate (39.4 kg/m3 at 78 K and 20 bar).
elements.clean_text: The hydrogen-adsorption isotherm also shows a two-step filling profile similar to that of O2 and N2 at low pressure. Interestingly, the desorption isotherm does not retrace the adsorption isotherm and shows an abrupt drop at ~14 bar. This remarkable hysteretic adsorption/desorption of H2 within FMOF-1, which has been reproduced three times, would allow H2 to be adsorbed at high pressures but stored at lower pressures. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first example of a hysteretic sorption behavior of supercritical H2 at a high-pressure range. The volumetric capacity of hydrogen within FMOF-1 at 77 K and 64 bar is 41 kg/m3, which is close to the DOE 2010 target of 45 kg/m3. Similar capacities have recently been reported at 77 K for Mn(II)-tetrazolate (43 kg/m3 at 90 bar) and Cu(II)-terphenyl-tetracarboxylate (39.4 kg/m3 at 78 K and 20 bar).

elements.content: Given that the densities of liquid O2, N2, and H2 are 1142, 804, and 70.8 kg/m3, respectively, the adsorption densities for O2 and N2 even at very low pressure (e.g., 592 and 427 kg/m3, respectively, at 0.03 bar) and for H2 at high pressure (e.g., 41 kg/m3 at 64 bar) suggest that the gas is highly compressed within the pores of FMOF-1. The volumetric gas uptake of FMOF-1 is the highest yet reported for O2 and among the best for H2.
elements.clean_text: Given that the densities of liquid O2, N2, and H2 are 1142, 804, and 70.8 kg/m3, respectively, the adsorption densities for O2 and N2 even at very low pressure (e.g., 592 and 427 kg/m3, respectively, at 0.03 bar) and for H2 at high pressure (e.g., 41 kg/m3 at 64 bar) suggest that the gas is highly compressed within the pores of FMOF-1. The volumetric gas uptake of FMOF-1 is the highest yet reported for O2 and among the best for H2.

elements.content: In conclusion, FMOF-1 represents a new class of porous materials with superior volumetric gas uptake. The unique hysteretic sorption of H2 into FMOF-1 paves a promising way for H2 to be filled at high pressures but stored at lower pressures. We expect that fluorous coordination polymers of this type will find applications in gas storage and separation, catalysis, sensors, switches, actuators, and n-type field-effect transistors.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, FMOF-1 represents a new class of porous materials with superior volumetric gas uptake. The unique hysteretic sorption of H2 into FMOF-1 paves a promising way for H2 to be filled at high pressures but stored at lower pressures. We expect that fluorous coordination polymers of this type will find applications in gas storage and separation, catalysis, sensors, switches, actuators, and n-type field-effect transistors.

References

cln_elements.content:
A fluorous metal−organic framework, FMOF-1, is obtained by reaction of Ag(I) with 3,5-bis(trifluoromethyl)-1,2,4-triazolate, giving rise to a neutral, hydrogen-free, extended 3D nanotubular porous framework consisting of tetranuclear clusters [Ag4Tz6] connected by three-coordinate Ag(I) centers. The fluoro-lined channels and cavities of the framework show hysteretic adsorption of H2 with a volumetric capacity of 41 kg/m3 at 77 K and 64 bar. The framework also exhibits very high adsorptions for O2 and N2 with volumetric uptake of ∼550 and 400 kg/m3 at 77 K even at very low pressures (<10-2 bar).

The architectural stability and porosity of FMOF-1 is confirmed by the gas adsorption results at 77 K (Figure ). The adsorption isotherms of O2 and N2 within FMOF-1 at low pressure show two pore-filling steps at log(P/P 0) of −4.0 and −3.2 for O2 and −4.0 and −2.7 for N2. It is reasonable to assign the first uptake to micropore filling of gas molecules into the large channels, whereas the second steep uptake is assigned to the small pores since the size of the latter (vide supra) can accommodate the dynamic size of the gas molecules studied herein (largest is N2, 4.1 Å × 3.0 Å). Fitting the BET equation to the N2 isotherm gives an apparent surface area of 810.5 m2/g and a pore volume of 0.324 cm3/g at P/P 0 = 0.978. These values surpass those of the most porous zeolites and are similar to those of the best-performing activated carbons and MOFs.

A fluorous metal-organic framework, FMOF-1, is obtained by reaction of Ag(I) with 3,5-bis(trifluoromethyl)-1,2,4-triazolate, giving rise to a neutral, hydrogen-free, extended 3D nanotubular porous framework consisting of tetranuclear clusters [Ag4Tz6] connected by three-coordinate Ag(I) centers. The fluoro-lined channels and cavities of the framework show hysteretic adsorption of H2 with a volumetric capacity of 41 kg/m3 at 77 K and 64 bar. The framework also exhibits very high adsorptions for O2 and N2 with volumetric uptake of ~550 and 400 kg/m3 at 77 K even at very low pressures (<10-2 bar). 

The architectural stability and porosity of FMOF-1 is confirmed by the gas adsorption results at 77 K (Figure ). The adsorption isotherms of O2 and N2 within FMOF-1 at low pressure show two pore-filling steps at log(P/P 0) of -4.0 and -3.2 for O2 and -4.0 and -2.7 for N2. It is reasonable to assign the first uptake to micropore filling of gas molecules into the large channels, whereas the second steep uptake is assigned to the small pores since the size of the latter (vide supra) can accommodate the dynamic size of the gas molecules studied herein (largest is N2, 4.1 Å × 3.0 Å). Fitting the BET equation to the N2 isotherm gives an apparent surface area of 810.5 m2/g and a pore volume of 0.324 cm3/g at P/P 0 = 0.978. These values surpass those of the most porous zeolites and are similar to those of the best-performing activated carbons and MOFs.

metadata.title: Fluorous Metal−Organic Frameworks for High-Density Gas Adsorption
